Question: For the purposes of administering and enforcing these sanctions, what powers do competent authorities have to issue directions, and to whom may such directions be addressed?

Passages.Passage:
5. A competent authority in the State, following such consultation as it 
considers necessary with other competent authorities, for the purposes of the 
administration and enforcement of the Council Regulation or these Regulations, 
may give in writing such directions to a person as it sees fit.

Question: In prosecutions for offences alleged to have been committed outside the State, what documentary evidence may be used to establish that the accused was an Irish citizen on the relevant date, and how is such evidence treated by the court?

Passages.Passage:
(3) In proceedings for an offence referred to in paragraph (1) - 

(a) 

(b) 

a certificate purporting to be signed by an officer of the 
Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and stating that a 
passport was issued by that Department to a person on a specified 
date, and 

a certificate that is signed by an officer of the Minister for Justice 
and stating that, to the best of the officer’s knowledge and belief, 
the person has not ceased to be an Irish citizen, 

is evidence that the person was an Irish citizen on the date on which the offence 
is alleged to have been committed, and is taken to have been signed by the person 
purporting to have signed it, unless the contrary is shown.

Question: Which powers and duties of the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment are delegated by this Order, and to whom is the delegation made, with any explicit exclusions?

Passages.Passage:
2. The powers (other than the power to prosecute an offence) and duties of 

the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment conferred on him – 

(a) by or under the enactments specified in Part 1 of the 

Schedule, 

(b) by or under the provision of the enactment specified in Part 2 of 

the Schedule, and 

(c) under the Regulations specified in Part 3 of the Schedule, 

are delegated to Dara Calleary, Minister of State at the Department of 
Enterprise, Trade and Employment.

Question: Do the delegated powers under this Order extend to matters under the Control of Exports legislation, and if so, which Acts are included within the scope of the delegation?

Passages.Passage:
Control of Exports Act 2008 (No. 1 of 2008) 

... 

Screening of Third Country Transactions Act 2023 (No. 28 of 2023) 

Control of Exports Act 2023 (No. 27 of 2023) 

Digital Services Act 2024 (No. 2 of 2024)

Question: Which specific social work activities are designated as industrial activities for the purposes of the Industrial Training Act 1967 under this Order?

Passages.Passage:
2. The following activities are hereby declared to be designated industrial 

activities for the purposes of the Industrial Training Act 1967 (No. 5 of 1967): 

(a) 

(b) 

(c) 

(d) 

the conduct of social work assessments of risk and protective 
factors impacting the safety and welfare of children and adults; 

the design, management, supervision and review of care and/or 
intervention plans; 

the delivery of social work interventions for individuals, 
families and communities; and 

the preparation of reports regarding the protection and welfare 
of children and adults at risk or in need of social services.

Question: When does this Industrial Training Order cease to apply to an activity because a separate industrial training order covers that activity?

Passages.Passage:
3. The provisions of this Order shall not apply to any activity of industry 

for which a separate industrial training order is, for the time being, in force.

Question: Who is appointed as Special Adviser by this Order, to which officeholder, and from what date does the appointment take effect?

Passages.Passage:
2. Daniel Griffin, particulars of whose address have been deposited at the 
offices of the Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media, 
is appointed as Special Adviser to Thomas Byrne, Minister of State at the 
Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media with effect 
from 10 April 2024.

Question: What procedural requirement regarding the appointee’s particulars is noted in the Order, and where must those particulars be deposited?

Passages.Passage:
2. Daniel Griffin, particulars of whose address have been deposited at the 
offices of the Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media, 
is appointed as Special Adviser to Thomas Byrne, Minister of State at the 
Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media with effect 
from 10 April 2024.

Question: Despite the general offence provision, under what conditions may a person lawfully perform acts that would otherwise contravene the Council Regulation concerning Burundi?

Passages.Passage:
4. Notwithstanding Regulation 3, a person who has received an 
authorisation under Article 3(1), 4(1) or 5(1) of the Council Regulation may, 
subject to compliance with the terms and conditions of such authorisation, do 
such of the things as are so authorised.

Question: What are the penalties for failing to comply, within the specified time, with a direction issued by a competent authority under these Regulations?

Passages.Passage:
7. A person who fails to comply with a direction given under Regulation 6 
within the time specified in the direction shall be guilty of an offence and shall 
be liable on summary conviction to a class A fine or to imprisonment for a 
term not exceeding 6 months or to both.

Question: Under what conditions may a person act lawfully despite a general prohibition in the Council Regulation concerning Venezuela, and which authorisations must they obtain to do so?

Passages.Passage: 4. Notwithstanding Regulation 3, a person who has received an authorisation under Article 4(1), 6(2), 9(1), 10(1) or 11(1) of the Council Regulation may, subject to compliance with the terms and conditions of such authorisation, do such of the things as are so authorised.

Question: What penalties apply to a person convicted under these Regulations, and how do they differ between summary conviction and conviction on indictment?

Passages.Passage: 5. A person who is guilty of an offence under Regulation 3 shall be liable - (a) on summary conviction, to a class A fine or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months or both, or (b) on conviction on indictment, to a fine not exceeding €500,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years or both.

Question: How do the 2024 amendments to the Local Government (Audit Committee) Regulations alter the committee’s engagement with Limerick City and County Council officials under the new mayoral system?

Passages.Passage: 6. Article 11 of the Principal Regulations is amended by the substitution of the following sub-article (2): “(2) The audit committee shall meet separately at least annually with— (a) the Local Government Auditor, (b) employees of the internal audit unit of the local authority, (c) the Chief Executive, and (d) as appropriate to his or her functions, in the case of Limerick City and County Council, the Mayor.”

Question: What new responsibility is placed on the audit committee chairperson following completion of a report under Article 15 of the Principal Regulations?

Passages.Passage: 7. Article 15 of the Principal Regulations is amended by the substitution of the following sub-article (2): “(2) On completion of the report prepared under paragraph (1), it shall be the duty of the Chairperson to send copies to the Chief Executive, in the case of Limerick City and County Council, to the Mayor, and to the local authority for consideration at the next practicable meeting.”

Question: What are the general conditions attached to a Wireless Telegraphy (Telemetry Licence) that a Licensee must comply with to avoid enforcement action?

Passages.Passage: 7. (1) It shall be a condition of a Licence that: (a) the Licensee shall comply with these Regulations and the conditions attached to the Licence; (b) the Licensee shall ensure that the Apparatus is used only on such radio frequency spectrum as may be specified in the Licence and such radio frequencies shall be used in an efficient manner; (c) the Licensee shall make payments of the fees as set out in Schedule 2; (d) the Licensee shall request the Commission to consider and decide on an amendment to the Licence to reflect any proposed changes to the information contained in the Licence; ... (p) ensure that all Apparatus, or any part thereof, complies with the Radio Equipment Regulations.

Question: How are Wireless Telegraphy Licence fees determined and adjusted over time under these Regulations?

Passages.Passage: SCHEDULE 2 FEES PAYABLE IN CONNECTION WITH LICENCES The Licence Fee is equal to the fee for that Licence in the base year (the “Base Fee”), indexed to the annual rate of inflation using the Consumer Price Index (“CPI”). ... The first indexation shall take place on the 8 July 2026 and shall occur annually thereafter on that same date.

Question: What forms of evidence may an applicant provide to establish themselves as an eligible family member under the Institutional Burials Act 2022?

Passages.Passage: 3. The evidence that a person is to provide for the purposes of establishing himself or herself as an eligible family member is prescribed for the purposes of section 42(1)(f) and 48(2)(a)(ii) of the Act: (a) An applicant may provide a Director with such public records, including but not limited to, birth certificates, marriage certificates or death certificates... (b) Where public records are not available or insufficient, an applicant may provide other records, including institutional or medical records; (c) A Director may request an affidavit; (d) A Director may use the powers under sections 27 and 29 of the Act to assess evidence.

Question: What procedures must a Director follow to contact eligible family members who may wish to object to participation in an Identification Programme?

Passages.Passage: 5. (1) The procedures for contacting an eligible family member are prescribed for the purposes of section 44(4) of the Act. (2) A Director may: (a) request contact information from another eligible family member; (b) use evidence provided under section 42(1)(f); (c) use powers under sections 27 and 29; or (d) identify additional means to obtain contact information. (3) If contact information is obtained, the Director shall attempt to make contact to provide information on rights of objection and deadlines.

Question: What powers do competent authorities possess under the European Union (Restrictive Measures concerning Sudan) Regulations 2024 to issue directions, and for what purposes?

Passages.Passage: 5. A competent authority in the State, following such consultation as it considers necessary with other competent authorities, for the purposes of the administration and enforcement of the Council Regulation or these Regulations, may give in writing such directions to a person as it sees fit.

Question: What liability arises for corporate officers where an offence under these Regulations is committed by a body corporate with their consent or neglect?

Passages.Passage: 7. Where an offence under these Regulations is committed by a body corporate and is proved to have been so committed with the consent or connivance of or to be attributable to any neglect on the part of any person, being a director, manager, secretary or other officer of the body corporate, or a person who was purporting to act in such capacity, that person shall, as well as the body corporate, be guilty of an offence and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished as if he or she were guilty of the first-mentioned offence.

Question: How do these Regulations redefine the constituencies entitled to elect producer members to the National Milk Agency, and what procedural changes are introduced regarding the conduct of the election?

Passages.Passage: 2. The National Milk Agency (Conduct of Elections) Regulations 1997 (S. I. No. 185 of 1997) are amended by: (a) substituting for Regulation 4(2) (as amended by the National Milk Agency (Conduct of Elections) (Amendment) Regulations 2021 (S.I. No. 373 of 2021), the following- “(2) (a) The registered producers who have supplied raw milk for heat treatment for liquid consumption to one or more of the following- (i) Tirlán Limited, (ii) Lakeland Dairies Co-Operative Society Limited, (iii) Aurivo Co-operative Society Limited, (iv) Glenisk Limited comprise a constituency and are entitled to elect 3 producer members to the National Milk Agency, and (b) The registered producers who have supplied raw milk for heat treatment for liquid consumption to one or more of the following– (i) The Village Dairy Limited, (ii) Mossfield Organic Farm Ltd., (iii) Bainne Codladh Ltd., (iv) Arrabawn Co-operative Society Limited, (v) Clona Dairy Products Society Limited, (vi) Dairygold Co-operative Society Limited (as agent for Tirlán Limited), (vii) Dawn Dairies Limited (Kerry Creameries Limited T/A Kerry Agribusiness – Dairies), (viii) Lee Strand Co-operative Creamery Limited, (ix) North Cork Co-operative Creameries Limited, (x) Centenary Thurles Co-operative Society Limited (Thurles Fresh Milk Limited) comprise a constituency and are entitled to elect 2 producer members to the National Milk Agency.”

Question: What new provisions do these Regulations introduce regarding the timing for receipt of nomination papers, ballot return day, and the counting of votes in National Milk Agency elections?

Passages.Passage: 2. ... the amendment of Regulation 13 by the substitution of “the closing date for receipt of nomination papers” for “the nomination day”, the amendment of Regulation 20(a) by the substitution of “the place and times for the counting of votes, the date (“the ballot return day”) by which completed ballot papers must be received by the returning officer;” for “the place and times for the counting of votes;” and the amendment of Regulation 28(1) by the substitution of “On the working day next following the ballot return day, or such other day as may be approved by the returning officer” for “At the hour of 2.00 p.m. on the day next following the day on which the return of all ballot papers issued at an election to the returning officer is completed”.

Question: Under the Immigration Act 2003 (Carrier Liability) Regulations 2024, what procedure is provided to carriers for discharging liability before prosecution, and what are the consequences of non-payment?

Passages.Passage: 3. (1) TAKE NOTICE, You may, during the period of 28 days beginning on the date of this notice, make to the Detective Superintendent (Administration) at Garda National Immigration Bureau, 13 - 14 Burgh Quay, Dublin 2 a payment of €2,500. (2) No prosecution in respect of the offence alleged will be instituted during the period of 28 days and if payment is made during that period, no prosecution in respect of the alleged offence will be instituted. (3) Failure to make payment in compliance of the terms of this notice will result in a prosecution. (4) Persons found guilty of an offence under section 2 shall be liable on summary conviction to a Class A fine for each offence.

Question: For which specific categories of offences under section 2 of the Immigration Act 2003 do these Regulations prescribe distinct forms of notice, and what statutory authority empowers their creation?

Passages.Passage: 3. The form of notice set out in Schedule 1 is prescribed for the purposes of section 3(1) of the Act of 2003 in relation to an offence under section 2(1)(a) of that Act. 4. The form of notice set out in Schedule 2 is prescribed for the purposes of section 3(1) of the Act of 2003 in relation to an offence under section 2(1)(b) of that Act. 5. The form of notice set out in Schedule 3 is prescribed for the purposes of section 3(1) of the Act of 2003 in relation to an offence under section 2(1)(c) of that Act. 6. The form of notice set out in Schedule 4 is prescribed for the purposes of section 3(1) of the Act of 2003 in relation to an offence under section 2(3)(a) of that Act. 7. The form of notice set out in Schedule 5 is prescribed for the purposes of section 3(1) of the Act of 2003 in relation to an offence under section 2(3)(b) of that Act.

Question: Who is appointed as Special Adviser under this Order, to which Minister is the appointment made, and from what date does it take effect?

Passages.Passage: 2. Ferghal Blaney, particulars of whose address have been deposited at the offices of the Department of Transport, is appointed to be a Special Adviser to James Lawless, Minister of State at the Department of Transport with effect from 18 July 2024.

Question: What procedural formalities accompany the appointment made by this Order, including the executing authority and publication requirements?

Passages.Passage:
GIVEN under the Official Seal of the Government,

3 September, 2024.

SIMON HARRIS,

Taoiseach.

Notice of the making of this Statutory Instrument was published in
'Iris Oifigiúil' of 6th September, 2024.

Question: Which ministers jointly made the Payment Scheme Act 2023 (section 49(4)) Regulations 2024, and what specific amendments do these Regulations introduce to Schedule 1 of the Act?

Passages.Passage: 3. Column 4 of Part 1 of Schedule 1 to the Act of 2023 is amended - (a) at reference number 3, by the substitution of “1958” for “1952”, (b) at reference number 18, by the substitution of “1960” for “1938”, (c) at reference number 25, by the substitution of “1960” for “1955”, and (d) at reference number 28, by the substitution of “1962” for “1936”. ... GIVEN under my Official Seal, 11 September, 2024. PASCHAL DONOHOE, Minister for Public Expenditure, National Development Plan Delivery and Reform. GIVEN under my Official Seal, 12 September, 2024. RODERIC O'GORMAN, Minister for Children, Equality, Disability, Integration and Youth.

Question: Under what statutory provision are the Payment Scheme Act 2023 (section 49(4)) Regulations 2024 made, and to what principal Act do they apply?

Passages.Passage: 1. Payment Scheme Act 2023 (section 49(4)) Regulations 2024. In these Regulations, “Act of 2023” means the Mother and Baby Institutions Payment Scheme Act 2023 (No. 20 of 2023).

Question: Who is appointed as Special Adviser to the Minister for Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media under this Order, and when does the appointment take effect?

Passages.Passage: 2. John Doody, particulars of whose address have been deposited at the offices of the Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media, is appointed as Special Adviser to the Minister for Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media with effect from 16 September 2024.

Question: What procedural formalities accompany the appointment of a Special Adviser under the Appointment of Special Adviser (Minister for Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media) (No. 2) Order 2024?

Passages.Passage: 2. John Doody, particulars of whose address have been deposited at the offices of the Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media, is appointed as Special Adviser to the Minister for Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media with effect from 16 September 2024. GIVEN under the Official Seal of the Government, 10 September, 2024. SIMON HARRIS, Taoiseach.

Question: Which specific provisions of the Legal Services Regulation Act 2015 are brought into operation by this Order, and how do they relate to legal partnerships?

Passages.Passage: 3. The 25th day of September 2024 is fixed as the day on which the following provisions of the Act of 2015 shall come into operation: (a) section 46 (insofar as it relates to legal partnerships); (b) section 47 (insofar as it relates to legal partnerships); (c) section 100; (d) section 101; (e) section 103 (insofar as it relates to legal partnerships); (f) section 104; (g) section 105; (h) section 113 (insofar as it relates to legal partnerships); (i) section 116 (insofar as it relates to legal partnerships); (j) section 117 (insofar as it relates to legal partnerships); (k) section 121 (other than subsection (2)); (l) section 178; (m) section 179; (n) section 201 (insofar as subsections (1)(c) and (1A), inserted by that section in section 26 of the Solicitors (Amendment) Act 1994, relate to legal partnerships).

Question: Under what authority is the Legal Services Regulation Act 2015 (Commencement of Certain Provisions) Order 2024 made, and what is its effect?

Passages.Passage: 1. This Order may be cited as the Legal Services Regulation Act 2015 (Commencement of Certain Provisions) Order 2024.

Question: When does Part 9 of the Courts, Civil Law, Criminal Law and Superannuation (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2024 come into operation, and under which statutory power is this Order made?

Passages.Passage: 2. The 30th day of September 2024 is appointed as the day on which Part 9 of the Courts, Civil Law, Criminal Law and Superannuation (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2024 (No. 30 of 2024) shall come into operation.

Question: What is the citation of the Order that commences Part 9 of the Courts, Civil Law, Criminal Law and Superannuation (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2024, and who is responsible for its issuance?

Passages.Passage: 1. This Order may be cited as the Courts, Civil Law, Criminal Law and Superannuation (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2024 (Part 9) (Commencement) Order 2024. GIVEN under my Official Seal, 20 September, 2024. HELEN MCENTEE, Minister for Justice.

Question: What amendments do these Regulations make to Article 182 of the Principal Regulations concerning the prescribed time for making claims to State pensions?

Passages.Passage: 4. Article 182 of the Principal Regulations (amended by article 7 of the Regulations of 2019) is amended by the substitution of the following paragraphs for paragraph (a): “(a) in the case of State pension (contributory), the period commencing 6 months before and ending 3 months after the date on which, apart from satisfying the condition of making a claim, the claimant becomes entitled thereto, (ab) in the case of State pension (transition) and invalidity pension, the period commencing 3 months before and ending 3 months after the date on which, apart from satisfying the condition of making a claim, the claimant becomes entitled thereto,”.

Question: According to the explanatory note, how do these Regulations alter the prescribed time limits for claiming the State Pension (Contributory), and what is the rationale for the change?

Passages.Passage: These Regulations amend the prescribed time for making a claim for State Pension (Contributory) so that a claim may be made up to 6 months before the date the person becomes entitled to State Pension (Contributory). From end October 2024, an online application form for state pension (contributory) and state pension (non-contributory) will be available to claimants. To align state pension (contributory) application timelines with the state pension (non-contributory), it is necessary to increase the prescribed time for state pension (contributory) from 3 to 6 months.

Question: What commencement date is specified for the Screening of Third Country Transactions Act 2023, and which Minister issues the Order bringing it into effect?

Passages.Passage: 2. The 6th day of January 2025 is appointed as the day on which the Screening of Third Country Transactions Act 2023 (No. 28 of 2023) shall come into operation. GIVEN under my hand, 17 December, 2024. DARA CALLEARY Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment.

Question: How is the commencement of the Screening of Third Country Transactions Act 2023 formally effected by this Order, and which officeholder executes it?

Passages.Passage:
2. The 6th day of January 2025 is appointed as the day on which the
Screening of Third Country Transactions Act 2023 (No. 28 of 2023) shall come
into operation.

GIVEN under my hand,
17 December, 2024.

DARA CALLEARY
 Minister of State at the Department of
 Enterprise, Trade and Employment.

Question: Which provisions of the Public Health (Tobacco Products and Nicotine Inhaling Products) Act 2023 are scheduled to commence on 2 February 2026 under this Order?

Passages.Passage: 2. The 2nd day of February 2026 is appointed as the day on which the following provisions of the Public Health (Tobacco Products and Nicotine Inhaling Products) Act 2023 (No. 35 of 2023) shall come into operation: (a) subsections (1)(a), (1)(b) and (2) of section 9; (b) Part 2; (c) section 25; (d) section 27; (e) section 32; (f) section 34; (g) section 39; (h) subsections (c) and (e) of section 45.

Question: What authority is cited for making the Public Health (Tobacco Products and Nicotine Inhaling Products) Act 2023 (Commencement) (No. 3) Order 2024, and who signed it?

Passages.Passage: GIVEN under my Official Seal, 17 December, 2024. STEPHEN DONNELLY, Minister for Health.
